Narcolepsy is a chronic neurological disorder that affects the brain\'s ability to regulate sleep-wake cycles. It is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness. Other classic symptoms of narcolepsy are cataplexy, sleep paralysis, and hallucinations. Unfortunately, an estimated 50% of people with narcolepsy remain undiagnosed.

Cataplexy is a sudden loss of muscle tone while a person is conscious. Oftentimes, it is triggered by sudden, strong emotions (e.g. laughter). Narcolepsy with cataplexy is called Type 1 narcolepsy. Narcolepsy without cataplexy is called Type 2 narcolepsy.

There may be several causes of narcolepsy. In particular, research suggests that narcolepsy with cataplexy is caused by loss of neurons that produce hypocretins, Hypocretin-1(orexin-A) and Hypocretin-2(orexin-B), neurotransmitters that promote wakefulness and suppress rapid-eye-movement (REM) sleep. There are also genetic factors, as most people with narcolepsy with cataplexy carry the gene human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQB1*0602, which is important for the immune system. This suggests that narcolepsy may be an autoimmune disorder, in which the immune system kills hypocretin-producing cells.

To establish a diagnosis of narcolepsy, two sleep tests are required: a polysomnogram(PSG, or overnight sleep study), and a multiple sleep latencytest(MSLT). Additionally, a clinical examination and detailed medical history are essential for the diagnosis and treatment of narcolepsy. Doctors may request their patients to keep a sleep journal over a one- to two- week period.

While there is no cure for narcolepsy, it can be effectively treated with a combination of medication and lifestyle changes. Medications commonly prescribed for narcolepsy include Modafinil, amphetamines and related stimulants, antidepressants, and sodium oxybate(Xyrem). Lifestyle changes include taking short naps, maintaining a regular sleep schedule, avoiding caffeine or alcohol before bed, and exercising daily.
